newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul bourse slump hits bank GDR issue plans - paper.
newsitem.headline: Seoul bourse slump hits bank GDR issue plans - paper.

text.p: The continued slump on the Seoul stock market has influenced South Korean banks to delay or scale down their plans to issue global depositary receipts abroad, a local newspaper reported on Sunday.
The Hankook Ilbo quoted a Boram Bank official as saying the bank's plan to issue $60 million worth of receipts abroad would be delayed due to the sluggish stock market.
"Investors in such markets as New York, London and Singapore shun investment in Korean instruments, citing the worsening situation in South Korea," the official was quoted as saying.
A plan by Korea Long-Term Credit Bank to issue $200 million worth of receipts abroad at around the end of October has also been delayed, the newspaper said.
Also hit by the languishing stock market, Cho Hung Bank's $180 million global depositary receipt issue in London was priced at a premium of only 1.0 percent.
Industry sources have said the premium was comparable with premiums of more than 10 percent that issues by leading South Korean firms had enjoyed earlier.
Cho Hung issued the receipts on November 27 and plans to list them on the London stock exchange later.
The Seoul stock market has been in the doldrums with the economic slowdown, and especially the widening foreign trade deficit, freezing investor sentiment.
The composite stock index plunged 27.4 percent to 715.97 on November 26 from this year's highest level of 986.84 in May. It later rebounded slightly to end Saturday's trading at 726.48.
